bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, September 16, 1940

div1.p: Moran describes his difficulties in dealing with the Cuban government regarding the Camp Lazear site. Moran will not attend the University of Virginia or the Washington and Jefferson College events.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, September 16, 1940
div1.opener:
Havana, Sept. 16, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter dated August 16th and a last-minute note
inclosed therewith, dated September 1st, reached me on September 10th
and your air-mail letter dated September 11th reached me on Sept. 14th.
Your 37-page memorandum has taken me the better part of a week to
digest and check. I have listed in orderly fashion the various items
called for in your memorandum and letters and will make every effort to
comply with your wishes. When I mention that it has taken me a week,
you will understand that I mean part time and evenings.

The information you call for from Dr. Ramos and other
Cuban medicos and Cubans will probably be denied you, especially in the
straightforward manner you would wish to have it. You will recall the
difficulty we had in “pinning down” any of them while you were here last
April. Due to your own status and the institution from which you hailed,
you were treated with a consideration which I could not command, then or
now. That being the case, you will appreciate that I cannot hope to
succeed where you failed. In truth you were not lacking in either per-
sistency or energy. When and as I can “catch up” with Dr. Ramos, I am
going to proceed along new lines in order to get him to acknowledge what
he already knows, viz: that the official site of “Camp Lazear” was select-
ed for convenience rather than for genuinity. If he does not “see the
light”, I will intimate in your behalf that Kissinger will be brought
here from the U. S. in order that the two of us may sign a joint affidavit
to the effect that Camp Lazear never was on the site officially claimed
for it; also that the sworn statements of Señora Rojas and her cousin are
to be obtained and filed with our own, all said documents to be lodged
with the proper authorities.

I will also inform Dr. Ramos that Americans in general
will welcome the present site for any memorial to Dr. Lazear and the
other membres of the Army Board, always providing that no tablets, slabs
or other form of word dedication will claim the site as the seat of the
experiments. You can rest assured that, when and as the Cuban Govern-
ment will move to perpetuate any such memorial, it will be 100% Finlay.

All other proofs obtainable today, by photographs or
otherwise, cannot restore the true site of Camp Lazear. In my humble
opinion, most of the ground upon which stood Camp Lazear has been ex-
cavated and converted into brick long ago. From 1901, when Camp Lazear
was abandoned, until 1936, no effort was made to perpetuate or mark the
site. Since Camp Lazear was a purely American affair, pertaining to the
Army of Occupation, it was incumbent on the Americans rather than the
Cubans to perpetuate the site or at least a part of it. For this, there
is a reason. Up to 1928-1929, little importance had been attached to
what General Kean referred to as “that now famous episode” and the sole
champion for many years favoring recognition for the members of the Board
and the “human guinea pigs” was General Kean himself. Formation of the
Committee (composed of a group of the most prominent men in the U. S)
seeking recognition for us all was principally due to the untiring efforts
and missionary work of General Kean, culminating in the Act of February
28th, 1929, with which you are familiar.

Unfortunately, when the “official Camp Lazear” was so hurriedly
selected, no effort was made to locate the real site. I am now sure
that, even though it had been located, the Cuban medicos connected with
the Department of Sanitation would not have planned on any form of memo-
rial on the ground which you and I went over so thoroughly. Dr. Ramos
and his associates were entirely willing to take Dr. Anglés' word for it.
Dr. Ramos has known for many years that I was one of the men experimented
upon at Camp Lazear. This was very intimately brought to his attention
about four or five years ago, when Prof. James E. Peabody was here and
gave a conference on the experiments at Ruston College, to which he was
invited. At that time he was Director of Sanitation. Dr. Agramonte's
daughter, one of the teachers at Ruston College, was also present. Doctor
Peabody insisted on my attendance and that of my Congressional Medal. In
illustrating his lecture, Dr. Peabody used the Metropolitan Life Insurance
Company's film, a copy of which I gave you when you were here.

It is my impression that the official Camp Lazear was precipi-
tately “discovered” in 1936 when Lieut-Col. Edgar Erskine Hume, Medical
Corps, U. S. Army, was the guest here of the Cuban Government. At that
time he was in charge of the Army Medical Library and it was during his
incumbency at the Library that I gave my Yellow Fever Certificate to the
Medical Corps of the Army, to be preserved with other letters and papers
of Major Reed at the Army Medical Library. When Colonel Hume was here
I tried on several occasions to see him and finally succeeded in making
an appointment with him at 1:00 P. M., at the National Hotel, on September
28, 1936, an appointment which, I regret to record, was kept by me but not
by Col. Hume. When I reached the hotel at the appointed hour I was in-
formed that Col. Hume was entertaining or being entertained by seven or
eight doctors of the Cuban Army and/or medicos of the Department of San-
itation. I properly calculated that further effort on my part to see
him would be fruitless, so I gave it up as a bad job. His time, while he
was here, was completely monopolized by the Cuban authorities and I am
reasonably sure he was glad when he finally made his departure. The
imitation bronze plaque which you saw in the “Sala Guiteras” (Guiteras
Ward) of Los Animas Hospital, dedicated to Dr. Lazear, was unveiled in
honor of Col. Hume while he was here. Please refer to the Albertini
address which I translated into English for you and mailed to you after
your departure from Havana. No, my friend, the Cubans interested in
Camp Lazear, either to further their own ends or willing to do something
to honor the memories of Major Reed and his associates, do not want to
discover the real site of Camp Lazear. All work which you have mapped
out for yourself to this end as well as all you have done to date is
“Love's Labor Lost”. The solution I have suggested in the second para-
graph of this letter is the best I can think of.

Just as soon as I can get in touch with Dr. Ramos and pin him
down to brass tacks in this matter, I will air-mail you his reaction to
it. In the meantime, I want to prepare you for the inevitable so that
you can set about revising the memorandum you sent to me. I shall send
you my own notes and observations on such points, items, etc. of the
memorandum as conflict with my own knowledge and understanding of any
such points in dispute. These will refer to dates, places, etc., your
personal opinion in all other matters at issue being yours by right.

You mention, my good friend, that “I got you into all this”.
I will admit that I did, indirectly. I still want you to write the
Reed-Finlay story because I feel sure you will do justice to both.
Dr. Philip S. Hench.
-- 3 --
Sept. 16, 1940.
Reconstruction or perpetuation of the site of Camp Lazear, however, did
not enter into my calculations. It is now too late to do that, for the
simple reason that those who might have retained a mental picture of
the camp and the exact place where it stood on the San José Farm or
“Finca San José”, cannot locate the plot, what with the buildings which
now exist on part of which might have been the site. It is almost certain
that neither Kissinger nor myself could assert at this day that Camp Lazear
was on the section we went over while you were here and it is equally certain
that Señora Rojas and her cousin, while they have watched the “Finca” in
process of being cut up into building sub-divisions and the excavations of
the soil suitable for brick-making, are extremely hazy on the point as to
just where the Camp was. In addition to this uncertainty, the marking
and perpetuation of Camp Lazear site would, of necessity, have to be a
affair in which the Cubans and Americans would be called upon to do their
respective shares. I will again repeat that Cuban support, Señora Rojas
aside, would not be forthcoming. I am reasonably sure that Dr. Ramos
will admit our claims, if presented in the manner I have outlined in the
second paragraph of this letter. That he will back any proposition to
set up any form of memorial on the plot where we thought Camp Lazear might
have been located, I doubt very much.

On second thought, I will await further instructions from you
before seeking my interview with Dr. Ramos and acting along the lines
suggested, in your name.

I have just received an invitation from the President of Wash-
ington & Jefferson College to be present at the dedication of the Lazear
Chemistry Building on October 25th and 26th. Before answering him, I
want to hear from you, since I propose NOT to accept the invitation. In
the first place, I cannot afford to spend the amount which the trip would
involve, since I feel that I would have to be accompanied by Mrs. Moran,
should I accept the inviation. My trip to Washington, last May, stood
me $300.00, between one thing and another. In the second place, while
Dr. Hutchison writes me that the College will pay my own personal
expenses, I could not accept such a proposition. To put it mildly, I
would find it embarrasing in the extreme. In the third place, I con-
sider that my place is in Cuba, in close contact with the affairs of
the company, for the rest of the year and until world affairs clear up
one way or the other. When you were here in April, I felt that there
would be no serious obstacle to prevent my acceptance of the invitation.
Much has happened since to knock many plans into a cocked hat. I wrote
Dean Jordan, of the Medical Department of the University of Virginia, that
I could not accept his invitation for a dinner in my honor at UVA on
October 25th, that being the date he had set. This happened some weeks
ago. Please do not think I have turned down the two invitations under
reference, lightly. On the contrary, I do so sadly and regretfully.
Acceptance of both would have meant much to me. Please let me hear from
you by RETURN AIR MAIL. Kindest personal remembrances to Mrs. Hench and
your good self from Elida and
div1.closer: Your sincere friend, John J. Moran.
